p: The presence of multiple third-level clades associated with recent livestock associated epidemic strains in the first level clade α and the relative paucity in clade β suggested that they may be under differential anthropogenic selection pressure. A key anthropogenic selection pressure on microbial populations circulating in livestock is the widespread use of antimicrobial drugs in animal husbandry. Consistent with their distinct epidemiology, antimicrobial resistance (AMR) genes were common in clades α (mean of 2.7 per strain) and relatively rare in β (mean 0.38 per strain) ( Fig 1A and S2 Table). Indeed, AMR genes in clade-β were restricted to strains from DT204/49 complex known to be associated with cattle [ 8] and the ST313 associated with disseminated disease in sub-Saharan Africa commonly treated with antibiotics [ 22].
